_comment: Expected scraper output â€” generated from kent.demo.data. Used by tests to verify the scraper extracts all data correctly. Archive local_path values are omitted since they depend on the runtime storage directory.

cases.summary: Plaintiff alleges defendant tunneled under his log without permission, causing subsidence and structural cracks in his prized bark collection.
Plaintiff claims defendant illegally assumed their identity during metamorphosis, a novel question of post-pupal personhood.

cases.case_name: Spider v. Fly ("Will You Walk Into My Parlour?")
cases.summary: Plaintiff alleges defendant breached the web-visiting agreement by arriving and immediately departing. The contract clearly states 'said the spider to the fly.'
Plaintiff claims defendant spread the Aesop fable to damage his reputation, calling him 'lazy' when in fact he is a freelance musician.
Plaintiff alleges unprovoked stinging incident at the Community Flower Garden. Defendant claims it was a case of mistaken identity—all yellow-and-black insects look alike to him.
Plaintiff seeks a restraining order citing persistent plant damage in her rose garden. Defendant counters that he has a constitutional right to feed.
Plaintiff claims defendant copied his patented bioluminescent signaling patterns, leading to confusion among potential mates at the meadow mixer.
Plaintiff alleges repeated unauthorized entry into her pond territory. Judge Swift has recused himself from dining-related aspects of this case.
A he-said-she-chirped dispute over nighttime noise levels. Plaintiff emerges every 17 years only to find defendant has been making a racket the entire time.
Plaintiff alleges defendant is undercutting wood-processing rates by 40%, constituting predatory pricing in the structural-demolition market.
Plaintiff alleges defendant stole his prized dung ball collection, valued at twelve acorns. Defendant claims she was merely 'browsing.'
Plaintiff claims injuries sustained from defendant's sudden appearance in her kitchen at 3 AM. Defense argues the kitchen is a public thoroughfare.

cases.case_name: Flea v. Dog Tick (Much Ado About Biting)
cases.summary: A biting dispute over host-mammal territory. Both parties claim exclusive biting rights to the neighborhood golden retriever. Expert witness: the dog, who declined to testify.
Plaintiff alleges defendant has been copying her iconic orange-and-black wing pattern for competitive advantage in the Mullerian mimicry marketplace.

cases.case_name: Bee Swarm LLC v. Hornet Inc.
cases.summary: A messy corporate divorce. The queen shareholders of Bee Swarm allege Hornet Inc. engaged in hostile takeover tactics, literally raiding the corporate hive.
Plaintiff alleges defendant consumed his rare first-edition copy of *The Metamorphosis* by Franz Kafka, causing irreparable literary and emotional damage.
Plaintiff alleges defendant violated the terms of their shared silo lease by producing larvae that consumed 60% of the wheat reserves.
Plaintiff claims defendant publicly described his natural defense mechanism as 'malodorous slander.' Defendant argues truth is an absolute defense.
Both parties are accused of impersonating foliage. Plaintiff claims his twig-mimicry was first, making defendant's leaf-mimicry a derivative work.
A probate dispute over the late Grand Moth's silk estate. Plaintiff, the largest moth in the world, argues wingspan should determine inheritance share.
Plaintiff is accused of setting fire to defendant's wooden mound structure. Defense argues his client's name is merely nominal and not indicative of pyromania.
A class action by the Locust Collective asserting their right to swarm. Defendant, a solitary grasshopper, argues that phase polyphenism is a choice, not a right.
Plaintiff alleges defendant used excessive force (specifically, 42 of his 100 legs) during a routine neighborhood dispute. Plaintiff curled into a ball.
Plaintiff discovered defendant had secretly laid eggs in her hive, a practice known in entomological law as 'brood parasitism in the first degree.'
A subterranean property dispute over tunneling rights. Plaintiff claims prescriptive easement; defendant argues he was there first by at least 400 million years.

cases.case_name: Cicada Emergence LLC v. Periodical Partners
cases.summary: Plaintiff alleges defendant breached their 17-year partnership agreement by emerging two years early, causing market saturation and decreased mate-finding efficiency.
Plaintiff holds Patent No. BIO-2019-LUX on 'ground-level bioluminescent attraction display.' Defendant counters that aerial bioluminescence is a distinct art.
Plaintiff, a licensed pest-control predator, was hired to eliminate defendant from a hotel but accidentally destroyed the minibar. Both parties seek damages.
Plaintiff alleges defendant stole his iridescent elytra for use in her personal collection. Defense: 'I was merely attracted to the shiny.'

Plaintiff accuses defendant of deploying cantharidin in a residential zone, violating the Geneva Conventions of the Garden. Defendant accuses plaintiff of hypocrisy, citing his own boiling-chemical defense mechanism.
